addressleaf.section:
To my very loving Friend M
r
Thomas Bodley Esq
r
her Ma
t
agent wth the [Stat]
of
e united provinc

page.lettertext:
fol.202r
M
r
Bodley: I am verie sorie to have cause at this present
to excuse my L. not writing to yo
w
, by his indisposition of bodie
whom nowe the Goute possesseth in his right hande: but beinge
commanded by his Lo: to deliver yo
w
the occasion of this silence, I trust
it shall suffize to cleare any conceipt in yo
w
, of any further neglect
toward
yo
w
. Yow shall understande, that some seaven or eight
daies since, my
LL
or the Counsell
being togeither to take some present
ordre for
e composicion of a Navie, and thereby falling into an account,
that some proporc
o
n must be had from other Contries; they thought it
fittt to send for
M
r
Caron
, to propownde to him a Request to be made
to
Thestates
(agreable to some Condycions of the Contracte) This
they should send to joyne w
th
her
Ma
tie
,
such convenient number
of shippes, as shee might thereby the better be inabled to defend
her selfe and them: wheruppon he made some difficultie; alleaging
therunto besid
, the great perturbac
o
ns they were in, by meanes of
yo
r
ernest prosecution of her Ma
t
demaund
: the LL
having
feelinglie perceaved by yo
r
wise and substantiall writing what yow
conceaved would be the sequeale (as of them selves) did only use this
speache. That if he could assure, that Thestat
would straine
them selves to any good proporc
o
n of this assistance; they would become
Intercessors to her May
tie
, to cease for
e present her further importuning
of the greater matter Commytted to yo
r
charg. Hee seemed hereuppon
very ready to intimate it to Thestat, when the LL going to
the Corte, found the Queene unresolved of this Course, and sent to him
to stay any such overture to be made to Thestat
, untill her Ma
tie
might more fully determyne: He confessed he had already dispatched
a Messenger to Comfort Thestat
, that he hoped well of bringing
it to passe, That for this seasonne the Queene would despence
w
th
them uppon that Condycion, and the LL
medyacion. Nowe S
r
To thintent yo
w
may not find it strang, if any such advertisemt have
preceded this yo
r
authenticall dispatche, I have thought good to
acquaint yo
w
w
th
all theise C ircumstanc
, as a matter well
knowen to my LL
, that dealt in it to be true, And nowe since that
fol.202v
their last l
re
s of
e xxviij
th
of October arryved, t[his resolucion]
hath succeeded, w
ch
nowe yow receave: and as I may [well referre]
yo
w
to it, being large, and w
th
the best warrant: so do[e I hope]
yo
w
will find by the stile varieng from
e former, that s[uch good]
Offices
in yo
r
in your particuler have ben performed, as [your]
Care, and dilligence hath deserved, and as yo
r
friend
[could]
possibly procure yo
w
: wherew
th
in haste, I recommend y[ow to Gods]
favour, and wishe yo
w
good successe thoughe I am not [hopefull]
of the last Article, w
ch
her may
tie
would need
have [inserted.]
From my house in
e
Strande
the seaventh of No[vember]1595.
Yo
r
very loving and assured Friende. Robert Cecyll
